Hello Randy,

Please see below. 

> What if we show qualitative results of =
multiple evolutionary runs? At that point, if the phenomenon is truly repro=
ducible across replicate evolutionary runs (w/ different seeds), then we al=
ready have a simple qualitative metric: How many replicates reproduced the =
phenomenon. Of course, that is a weak qualitative analysis, but if other me=
asures are lacking, it would still be more informative than saying, "this t=
echnique worked once (here's a video)."
> 
> 

That's only true if you can =
quantitatively measure the phenomenon. **If** you can do that, then of cour=
se you should report quantitative metrics on it (with p-values, effect size=
s, etc.). But my point is about results that you can't quantify. Should the=
y be categorically excluded because they resist quantification? 

For examp=
le, are the 3D shapes produced by CPPNs on EndlessForms interestingly diffe=
rent from those produced by L-Systems? Are the images on Picbreeder.com mor=
e complex and nuanced than--or at least, interestingly different from--the =
images from Dawkins' Biomorphs? I think the answer is clearly yes, but any =
attempt to quantify that would be a wasted exercise: the quantification wou=
ld be full of problems, and you'd spend a lot of time forcing a quantitativ=
e assessment of something that is patently obvious to every human being. Wh=
y force ourselves to jump through that wasteful, and unhelpful, hoop?

> Le=
t's ground this idea with a concrete example. Last year at ALife, one of th=
e presenters in the Artificial Life track presented work where (they openly=
 admitted) that the phenomenon only occurred 1 out of 100 replicates. IOW, =
the researcher had N=3D1. They went on to talk about how the environment sh=
aped the observed phenomenon in that single replicate. Would this ever pass=
 in any other field? Would *you* believe that the environment had any effec=
t with N=3D1? Effectively, that is what showing a qualitative result is.
> =

> 
I am not going to defend that practice unless it was just a proof of co=
ncept that the phenomenon can happen (as Julian points out). Something occu=
rring once is only a demonstration that it *can* happen, but of course if i=
t happens only once then very little else can be concluded. 

> In science,=
 it is vital to show that our results are reproducible and measurable. Thus=
, by that very nature, we must provide a quantitative analysis of our resul=
ts. However, in my (and many others') view, I do not think that how the res=
ults are presented is the core problem. Rather, the problem lies in how the=
 experiments are designed and the hypotheses addressed (or lack thereof).
>=
 
> ### Hypothesis testing ###
> 
> This is an argument that was huge in th=
e biology community some 50 years ago. I refer to, e.g., "Strong Inference"=
 by J Platt (1964). What is the best (or, most expedient) way to do science=
? Platt's paper has some great quotes, and he eloquently touches on some re=
levant subjects for the very conversation we are having here.
> 
> First, l=
et's touch on the culture of method development. Too much research focuses =
on method development rather than testing a hypothesis that actually advanc=
es the field. I've read too many papers that say, "we hypothesize that our =
method will work in task A." That's technically a testable hypothesis, but =
what does testing that hypothesis really tell us? Has anyone outside of you=
r work group actually wondered about that question? Testing that hypothesis=
 just shows that our method works on task A, but like JBM said, the field a=
s a whole doesn't actually learn much from it.
> 
> Instead of showing that=
 our method works on task A, we can address broader hypotheses with the met=
hod. What is it about our method that allows it to work on task A? For exam=
ple, what fundamental body plan does a robot need for an evolved ANN to con=
trol it? ["Morphological change in machines accelerates the evolution of ro=
bust behavior", Bongard (2011)] Or, how does using a generative encoding vs=
. a direct encoding affect mutation effect size? ["Evolving Coordinated Qua=
druped Gaits with the HyperNEAT Generative Encoding", Clune et al. (2009)] =
These papers demonstrated new methods while also answering questions that a=
re broadly interesting beyond that method. Method development should occur =
*alongside* the science, but it should not be the focus of the science itse=
lf.
> 
> 
I completely agree with you. 

> What's worse, this culture of me=
thod development has led to a culture of method comparison, e.g., "our meth=
od outperforms method X on benchmark A." In this kind of work, method devel=
opment really is the focus of the research. As Ken attests, after spending =
months reading this kind of literature, it leaves you knowing little more t=
han "method X is better than method Y on tasks A, B, and C." This kind of w=
ork has no lasting effect because the hypotheses it addresses are weak.
> 
=
> As such, the field would benefit from researchers focusing more on what b=
roader hypotheses they want to address with their work, rather than what me=
thod will produce a phenomenon. What broadly interesting questions can we a=
nswer with our method?
> 
> 
Amen! But I don't think that agreeing with you=
 also means that we should rule out hard-to-quantify results if they are in=
teresting for testing broader hypotheses. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:
> =
>
> > 
> > 
> > Hi JBM, thanks for getting deeper into this fascinating iss=
ue of how we can be confident that a paper has strong results. I hope you d=
on't mind that I changed the subject line to make this thread easier to fin=
d in the future.
> > 
> > I think we all broadly agree that there is no sin=
gle formula for a good paper and you and Jeff are arguing more about matter=
s of degree. I am very interested in this subject as you know and I think i=
t merits a lot more attention than it usually gets, which is one reason I'm=
 glad you got deeper into it. So here I want to add some more weight to the=
 case for qualitative papers. I should warn everyone up front that I took t=
his opportunity basically to write an essay, so this is a long post full of=
 my thoughts on this issue.
> > 
> > I believe most people in our field wou=
ld agree with JBM's assertion that there is "a strong correlation between w=
eak papers and papers without strong quantitative results."
> > 
> > I want=
 to question that assumption because I do not believe it is true even thoug=
h it is widely assumed to be true and in fact is perhaps the engine behind =
the entire reviewing philosophy in AI. In fact, this issue of how science s=
hould progress is ultimately not a scientific issue but a philosophical iss=
ue. That is, when you begin to discuss which kinds of results are most usef=
ul for future progress, it is a meta-discussion about how science progresse=
s. Paul Feyerabend, who was a kind of radical philosopher of science, has a=
 really nice quote on this issue that I find inspirational: 
> > 
> > "To t=
hose who look at the rich material provided by history, and who are not int=
ent on impoverishing it in order to please their lower instincts, their cra=
ving for intellectual security in the form of clarity, precision, 'objectiv=
ity', 'truth', it will become clear that there is only one principle that c=
an be defended under all circumstances and in all stages of human developme=
nt. It is the principle: anything goes." 
> > Against Method: Outline of an=
 Anarchistic Theory of Knowledge (1975)
> > 
> > My personal experience fit=
s very well with this idea. There will be times in history where quantifica=
tion is what we need, and other times when it is the last thing we need. An=
d I believe the worship of quantification has recently, at this point in th=
e history of our field, been mostly an obstacle to progress put in place by=
 those "craving for intellectual security," as Feyerabend puts it. But inse=
curity is not a good foundation for the building of wisdom because explorat=
ion requires courage and a willingness to confront ambiguity. Quantificatio=
n at this time in AI is largely an attempt to escape from ambiguity, and th=
ereby becomes a form of deception.
> > 
> > Consider what I have called the=
 "objective paradox": often if you measure the ability of a method or encod=
ing in EC to achieve a specific objective, your conclusions about what that=
 method can achieve in general will be entirely skewed and misleading. Targ=
et-based benchmarks, rather than giving confidence, are causing us to miss =
the forest for the trees. Think how in my paper with Brian Woolley (http://=
eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2011/woolley-gecco11) we could not re-evolve =
many images on Picbreeder with NEAT and CPPNs (which are the very methods b=
ehind Picbreeder). So in the quantitative world we would conclude that CPPN=
s cannot evolve such images. And in fact results of this sort (showing meth=
od X cannot solve problem A) are published all the time, and almost entirel=
y misleading. 
> > 
> > They are also the basis of highly deceptive compari=
sons between method X and Y. We like to say if method X "performs significa=
ntly better" than method Y on task A then method X is somehow "better." But=
 the truth is that often the ability of an encoding to evolve to a specific=
 target is a bad sign for its ability to ever produce anything interesting.=
 Think about direct encodings: they will always win on low-dimensional targ=
et-matching problems but are a dead end for evolving anything truly complex=
. We are fooling ourselves with quantification.
> > 
> > Even people who ar=
e aware of Woolley's result and agree with our conclusions *still* publish =
this kind of result because our culture is so deeply entrenched in this kin=
d of quantification that we simply have no idea what else to do. If we were=
 willing to truly embrace the absurdity of this kind of analysis, someone w=
ould have the courage to proclaim that DNA is incapable of evolving humans =
(which were of course never set as the objective of evolution). After all, =
if humans were set as objective targets for evolution from the start, there=
 would be no humans. 
> > 
> > How many of us have tried to test method X o=
n objective A and found method X wanting and then published the result? And=
 how many such papers would you consider "strong?" Our culture of worshippi=
ng quantification has often led us astray on the real power of evolution an=
d the potential of different encodings. If intuition trumped quantification=
 (a heretical suggestion) this fundamental confusion would not have arisen =
so severely.
> > 
> > Now I want to look at this issue from the opposite di=
rection, where my own experience has been much more positive: how qualitati=
ve observations often lead to unexpected leaps of insight in a way quantita=
tive results rarely have for me. In fact, almost every idea in which I have=
 been involved is the result of a qualitative observation, exactly the kind=
 that worshipers of quantification seem to want to prevent us from publishi=
ng and sharing with each other. 
> > 
> > For example, before I thought of =
NEAT I read dozens of neuroevolution papers (this was in the Fall of 1999).=
 There were tons of quantitative results and comparisons, but at the end of=
 four months of reading all this literature, I did not remember any of the =
quantitative results. Instead, what was left with me was a "feeling" that s=
omething qualitative was missing: Regardless of performance, none of these =
methods had the feel of nature when it came to the tendency for complexity =
to increase elegantly and indefinitely. And that is where the inspiration f=
or NEAT began, by ignoring quantitative results. If I had followed them, I =
would simply have built upon the "best" neuroevolution method of the time, =
which had been my original plan, having been brought up too in the culture =
of quantification. So then there would be no NEAT.
> > 
> > My idea for CPP=
Ns was also from an entirely qualitative observation. It actually came befo=
re Picbreeder. The main insight was actually from evolving a spaceship imag=
e in Mattias Fagerlund's old NEAT-based Genetic Art program. The experience=
 of evolving the spaceship was so exciting to me at the time that I put up =
a whole website on it: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/rocket.html =

> > 
> > There was not a single quantitative result, but I was convinced t=
hat I had seen something, qualitatively, that resonated with nature. It was=
 that qualitative feeling, that recognition of something deep in the result=
s, that led to CPPNs. It was a couple years later that the whole theory sol=
idified and I wrote the journal article on CPPNS: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/p=
ublications/2007/stanley-gpem07
> > 
> > One interesting thing about that C=
PPN journal article is that it is almost entirely qualitative. As you can i=
magine, that posed problems for review, but I was determined not to pollute=
 it with meaningless quantification. For me, the images speak for themselve=
s.
> > 
> > Those observations on CPPNs and their resulting symmetries and =
regularities are also what led to David D'Ambrosio, Jason Gauci and myself =
creating HyperNEAT - again, the inspiration for the idea was not any quanti=
tative demonstration of anything. 
> > 
> > And finally, as some of you kno=
w, novelty search itself was not inspired by a quantitative result. Rather,=
 it comes *again* from evolving pictures - in this case it was my experienc=
e of evolving the Picbreeder Car: picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=
=3D464
> > What shocked me from the experience of evolving the car was that=
 I had not been trying to evolve a car. I could not stop thinking about tha=
t, about how I did something really hard (from a qualitative perspective) b=
y not trying to do it. I later noticed that almost every interesting image =
on the site has the same strange story. I discussed the implications of the=
se observations with Joel Lehman, which led us both to novelty search.
> > =

> > Now someone could argue that these ideas may all turn out "weak" in th=
e end. But that would be a strange philosophy of science; it would suggest =
that we should never have explored down these roads in the first place. Of =
course we cannot know where any road leads until we take it - and I think a=
t least it's clear these were roads worth exploring though no one can say t=
hey lead ultimately to the greatest truths. But it's still worth the lesson=
s along the way. 
> > 
> > Someone might also think, okay, your inspiration=
s may have been qualitative but your *results* were mainly quantitative, an=
d somehow that's what matters (though recall the CPPN paper does not have q=
uantitative results). As JBM points out, our novelty search paper did have =
quantitative results that ultimately convinced him something interesting wa=
s going on. But I think again the focus here on "results" misses the forest=
 for the trees. What is more important for the progress of science than the=
 results is the *inspiration* that leads to the ideas that produced the res=
ults. If the inspiration is withheld, if I cannot share with you the analog=
ue of the spaceship or the car in the future, then you can never draw from =
those inspirations to find new roads for us to travel. The kind of science =
that I believe JBM and many others idealize cuts out all the inspiration fr=
om the public sphere and leaves us only to share its fruits when someone is=
 lucky enough in private to see something interesting (and try to quantify =
it then).
> > 
> > Nevertheless, JBM says, "I think that it is much harder =
to write a convincing paper without any quantitative test than with the hel=
p of measures/comparisons/etc." Again, many would share this sentiment. But=
 if you think about it, what exactly do we need to be "convinced" of? Why d=
o we think science (or AI especially) is about convincing someone of someth=
ing? Why do we need e.g. 30 strangers to validate an intuition we already f=
eel deeply that something is interesting? The links in the chain of progres=
s are from inspiration, not from convincing. There are many ideas that are =
neither right nor wrong anyway, but worth exploring because they will lead =
us to new revelations. To me, capturing the essence of nature is as much ab=
out a feeling as it is about a result. And my experience in practice bears =
that out.
> > 
> > Here is where I want to return to the intellectual insec=
urity that Feyerabend raises. I think our quantitative culture all boils do=
wn to this problem of insecurity. We do not trust ourselves to have valid i=
ntuitions. We dismiss our own ability to think, as with JBM's tongue-in-che=
eck parody, "look, cool simulated robots." But I want to question why we ar=
e so insecure in our own qualitative judgments? 
> > 
> > For those of us w=
ith PhDs, our countries invested something like 25 years into our education=
. Shouldn't someone who supposedly succeeded in jumping through intellectua=
l hoop after hoop after hoop - eventually impressing their peers enough to =
be hired, even eventually to be tenured or promoted - be able to think for =
themselves sufficiently to decide whether the "cool robots" are worth shari=
ng with other scientists because they might inspire new ideas? If we are re=
ally entirely unqualified after all those years of supposedly learning to b=
e a scientist, then what was the use of all that public investment? Was it =
simply to validate that we are able to check p-values that someone else rep=
orts in an X vs. Y quantitative comparison? That's all we're qualified to d=
o? Why do we deny our intellectual curiosity and ability to think for ourse=
lves? 
> > 
> > You may think it can't be done. Maybe you think my personal=
 experience with NEAT, CPPNs, HyperNEAT, novelty search, etc. is some kind =
of fluke that doesn't really represent science and how it works. Maybe you =
think that kind of qualitative approach may work for Ken for some reason bu=
t it can't work in general. But why would that be? Isn't it possible that w=
e are all prematurely discrediting our intellectual potential to think for =
ourselves? We have created a culture in which the spaceships and cars of sc=
ience must be hidden, buried until their discoverers figure out (or give up=
 figuring out) their deeper implications. I do not support publishing a pap=
er simply because of some "cool robots," but I do support qualified scienti=
sts deciding for themselves, from their experience and intuitions, whether =
those cool robots might be the seed of an important chain of ideas. And I d=
o not want those cool robots hidden from me as a reader of scientific liter=
ature if they might be such a seed. When I looked at Jeff's recent video of=
 his cool robots, I could feel those wheels of intuition turning in my mind=
. I still don't know if it leads to anything, but I don't need any quantifi=
cation to know that that feeling is more than enough to justify publishing =
that paper, and I'm grateful he and his coauthors did not try to obfuscate =
it with a veil of needless quantification.
> > 
> > Best,
> > 
> > ken
> 
>=

the research. As Ken attests, after spending months reading this kind of li=
terature, it leaves you knowing little more than "method X is better than m=
ethod Y on tasks A, B, and C." This kind of work has no lasting effect beca=
use the hypotheses it addresses are weak.<br>
<br>
As such, the field would=
 benefit from researchers focusing more on what broader hypotheses they wan=
t to address with their work, rather than what method will produce a phenom=
enon. What broadly interesting questions can we answer with our method?<br>=

<br></p></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div>Amen! But I don't think =
that agreeing with you also means that we should rule out hard-to-quantify =
results if they are interesting for testing broader hypotheses. </div>=

--- In =
<a href=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, "Ken" &=
lt;kstanley@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> <br>
> <br>
> Hi JBM, th=
anks for getting deeper into this fascinating issue of how we can be confid=
ent that a paper has strong results.  I hope you don't mind that I changed =
the subject line to make this thread easier to find in the future.<br>
>=
 <br>
> I think we all broadly agree that there is no single formula for=
 a good paper and you and Jeff are arguing more about matters of degree.  I=
 am very interested in this subject as you know and I think it merits a lot=
 more attention than it usually gets, which is one reason I'm glad you got =
deeper into it.  So here I want to add some more weight to the case for qua=
litative papers.  I should warn everyone up front that I took this opportun=
ity basically to write an essay, so this is a long post full of my thoughts=
 on this issue.<br>
> <br>
> I believe most people in our field would=
 agree with JBM's assertion that there is "a strong correlation between wea=
k papers and papers without strong quantitative results."<br>
> <br>
&gt=
; I want to question that assumption because I do not believe it is true ev=
en though it is widely assumed to be true and in fact is perhaps the engine=
 behind the entire reviewing philosophy in AI.  In fact, this issue of how =
science should progress is ultimately not a scientific issue but a philosop=
hical issue.  That is, when you begin to discuss which kinds of results are=
 most useful for future progress, it is a meta-discussion about how science=
 progresses.  Paul Feyerabend, who was a kind of radical philosopher of sci=
ence, has a really nice quote on this issue that I find inspirational: <br>=

> <br>
> "To those who look at the rich material provided by history=
, and who are not intent on impoverishing it in order to please their lower=
 instincts, their craving for intellectual security in the form of clarity,=
 precision, 'objectivity', 'truth', it will become clear that there is only=
 one principle that can be defended under all circumstances and in all stag=
es of human development. It is the principle: anything goes." <br>
> Aga=
inst Method: Outline of an Anarchistic Theory of Knowledge (1975)<br>
> =
<br>
> My personal experience fits very well with this idea.  There will=
 be times in history where quantification is what we need, and other times =
when it is the last thing we need.  And I believe the worship of quantifica=
tion has recently, at this point in the history of our field, been mostly a=
n obstacle to progress put in place by those "craving for intellectual secu=
rity," as Feyerabend puts it.  But insecurity is not a good foundation for =
the building of wisdom because exploration requires courage and a willingne=
ss to confront ambiguity.  Quantification at this time in AI is largely an =
attempt to escape from ambiguity, and thereby becomes a form of deception.<=
br>
> <br>
> Consider what I have called the "objective paradox": oft=
en if you measure the ability of a method or encoding in EC to achieve a sp=
ecific objective, your conclusions about what that method can achieve in ge=
neral will be entirely skewed and misleading.  Target-based benchmarks, rat=
her than giving confidence, are causing us to miss the forest for the trees=
.  Think how in my paper with Brian Woolley (<a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf=
.edu/publications/2011/woolley-gecco11">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publication=
s/2011/woolley-gecco11</a>) we could not re-evolve many images on Picbreede=
r with NEAT and CPPNs (which are the very methods behind Picbreeder).  So i=
n the quantitative world we would conclude that CPPNs cannot evolve such im=
ages.  And in fact results of this sort (showing method X cannot solve prob=
lem A) are published all the time, and almost entirely misleading.  <br>
&g=
t; 	<br>
> They are also the basis of highly deceptive comparisons betwe=
en method X and Y.  We like to say if method X "performs significantly bett=
er" than method Y on task A then method X is somehow "better."  But the tru=
th is that often the ability of an encoding to evolve to a specific target =
is a bad sign for its ability to ever produce anything interesting.  Think =
about direct encodings:  they will always win on low-dimensional target-mat=
ching problems but are a dead end for evolving anything truly complex.  We =
are fooling ourselves with quantification.<br>
> <br>
> Even people w=
ho are aware of Woolley's result and agree with our conclusions *still* pub=
lish this kind of result because our culture is so deeply entrenched in thi=
s kind of quantification that we simply have no idea what else to do.  If w=
e were willing to truly embrace the absurdity of this kind of analysis, som=
eone would have the courage to proclaim that DNA is incapable of evolving h=
umans (which were of course never set as the objective of evolution).  Afte=
r all, if humans were set as objective targets for evolution from the start=
, there would be no humans.  <br>
> <br>
> How many of us have tried =
to test method X on objective A and found method X wanting and then publish=
ed the result?  And how many such papers would you consider "strong?"  Our =
culture of worshipping quantification has often led us astray on the real p=
ower of evolution and the potential of different encodings.  If intuition t=
rumped quantification (a heretical suggestion) this fundamental confusion w=
ould not have arisen so severely.<br>
> <br>
> Now I want to look at =
this issue from the opposite direction, where my own experience has been mu=
ch more positive: how qualitative observations often lead to unexpected lea=
ps of insight in a way quantitative results rarely have for me.  In fact, a=
lmost every idea in which I have been involved is the result of a qualitati=
ve observation, exactly the kind that worshipers of quantification seem to =
want to prevent us from publishing and sharing with each other.  <br>
> =
<br>
> For example, before I thought of NEAT I read dozens of neuroevolu=
tion papers (this was in the Fall of 1999).  There were tons of quantitativ=
e results and comparisons, but at the end of four months of reading all thi=
s literature, I did not remember any of the quantitative results.  Instead,=
 what was left with me was a "feeling" that something qualitative was missi=
ng:  Regardless of performance, none of these methods had the feel of natur=
e when it came to the tendency for complexity to increase elegantly and ind=
efinitely.  And that is where the inspiration for NEAT began, by ignoring q=
uantitative results.  If I had followed them, I would simply have built upo=
n the "best" neuroevolution method of the time, which had been my original =
plan, having been brought up too in the culture of quantification.  So then=
 there would be no NEAT.<br>
> <br>
> My idea for CPPNs was also from=
 an entirely qualitative observation.  It actually came before Picbreeder. =
 The main insight was actually from evolving a spaceship image in Mattias F=
agerlund's old NEAT-based Genetic Art program.  The experience of evolving =
the spaceship was so exciting to me at the time that I put up a whole websi=
te on it: <a href=3D"http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/rocket.html">h=
ttp://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/rocket.html</a>  <br>
> <br>
>=
 There was not a single quantitative result, but I was convinced that I had=
 seen something, qualitatively, that resonated with nature.  It was that qu=
alitative feeling, that recognition of something deep in the results, that =
led to CPPNs.  It was a couple years later that the whole theory solidified=
 and I wrote the journal article on CPPNS: <a href=3D"http://eplex.cs.ucf.e=
du/publications/2007/stanley-gpem07">http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2=
007/stanley-gpem07</a><br>
> <br>
> One interesting thing about that =
CPPN journal article is that it is almost entirely qualitative.  As you can=
 imagine, that posed problems for review, but I was determined not to pollu=
te it with meaningless quantification. For me, the images speak for themsel=
ves.<br>
> <br>
> Those observations on CPPNs and their resulting sym=
metries and regularities are also what led to David D'Ambrosio, Jason Gauci=
 and myself creating HyperNEAT - again, the inspiration for the idea was no=
t any quantitative demonstration of anything.  <br>
> <br>
> And fina=
lly, as some of you know, novelty search itself was not inspired by a quant=
itative result.  Rather, it comes *again* from evolving pictures - in this =
case it was my experience of evolving the Picbreeder Car: <a href=3D"http:/=
/picbreeder.org/search/showgenome.php?sid=3D464">picbreeder.org/search/show=
genome.php?sid=3D464</a><br>
> What shocked me from the experience of ev=
olving the car was that I had not been trying to evolve a car.  I could not=
 stop thinking about that, about how I did something really hard (from a qu=
alitative perspective) by not trying to do it.  I later noticed that almost=
 every interesting image on the site has the same strange story.  I discuss=
ed the implications of these observations with Joel Lehman, which led us bo=
th to novelty search.<br>
> <br>
> Now someone could argue that these=
 ideas may all turn out "weak" in the end.  But that would be a strange phi=
losophy of science; it would suggest that we should never have explored dow=
n these roads in the first place.  Of course we cannot know where any road =
leads until we take it - and I think at least it's clear these were roads w=
orth exploring though no one can say they lead ultimately to the greatest t=
ruths.  But it's still worth the lessons along the way.  <br>
> <br>
&gt=
; Someone might also think, okay, your inspirations may have been qualitati=
ve but your *results* were mainly quantitative, and somehow that's what mat=
ters (though recall the CPPN paper does not have quantitative results).  As=
 JBM points out, our novelty search paper did have quantitative results tha=
t ultimately convinced him something interesting was going on.  But I think=
 again the focus here on "results" misses the forest for the trees.  What i=
s more important for the progress of science than the results is the *inspi=
ration* that leads to the ideas that produced the results.  If the inspirat=
ion is withheld, if I cannot share with you the analogue of the spaceship o=
r the car in the future, then you can never draw from those inspirations to=
 find new roads for us to travel.  The kind of science that I believe JBM a=
nd many others idealize cuts out all the inspiration from the public sphere=
 and leaves us only to share its fruits when someone is lucky enough in pri=
vate to see something interesting (and try to quantify it then).<br>
> <=
br>
> Nevertheless, JBM says, "I think that it is much harder to write a=
 convincing paper without any quantitative test than with the help of measu=
res/comparisons/etc."  Again, many would share this sentiment.  But if you =
think about it, what exactly do we need to be "convinced" of?  Why do we th=
ink science (or AI especially) is about convincing someone of something?  W=
hy do we need e.g. 30 strangers to validate an intuition we already feel de=
eply that something is interesting?  The links in the chain of progress are=
 from inspiration, not from convincing.  There are many ideas that are neit=
her right nor wrong anyway, but worth exploring because they will lead us t=
o new revelations.  To me, capturing the essence of nature is as much about=
 a feeling as it is about a result.  And my experience in practice bears th=
at out.<br>
> <br>
> Here is where I want to return to the intellectu=
al insecurity that Feyerabend raises.  I think our quantitative culture all=
 boils down to this problem of insecurity.  We do not trust ourselves to ha=
ve valid intuitions.  We dismiss our own ability to think, as with JBM's to=
ngue-in-cheeck parody, "look, cool simulated robots."  But I want to questi=
on why we are so insecure in our own qualitative judgments?  <br>
> <br>=

> For those of us with PhDs, our countries invested something like 25 y=
ears into our education.  Shouldn't someone who supposedly succeeded in jum=
ping through intellectual hoop after hoop after hoop - eventually impressin=
g their peers enough to be hired, even eventually to be tenured or promoted=
 - be able to think for themselves sufficiently to decide whether the "cool=
 robots" are worth sharing with other scientists because they might inspire=
 new ideas?  If we are really entirely unqualified after all those years of=
 supposedly learning to be a scientist, then what was the use of all that p=
ublic investment?  Was it simply to validate that we are able to check p-va=
lues that someone else reports in an X vs. Y quantitative comparison?  That=
's all we're qualified to do?  Why do we deny our intellectual curiosity an=
d ability to think for ourselves?  <br>
> <br>
> You may think it can=
't be done.  Maybe you think my personal experience with NEAT, CPPNs, Hyper=
NEAT, novelty search, etc. is some kind of fluke that doesn't really repres=
ent science and how it works.  Maybe you think that kind of qualitative app=
roach may work for Ken for some reason but it can't work in general.  But w=
hy would that be?  Isn't it possible that we are all prematurely discrediti=
ng our intellectual potential to think for ourselves?  We have created a cu=
lture in which the spaceships and cars of science must be hidden, buried un=
til their discoverers figure out (or give up figuring out) their deeper imp=
lications.  I do not support publishing a paper simply because of some "coo=
l robots," but I do support qualified scientists deciding for themselves, f=
rom their experience and intuitions, whether those cool robots might be the=
 seed of an important chain of ideas.  And I do not want those cool robots =
hidden from me as a reader of scientific literature if they might be such a=
 seed.  When I looked at Jeff's recent video of his cool robots, I could fe=
el those wheels of intuition turning in my mind.  I still don't know if it =
leads to anything, but I don't need any quantification to know that that fe=
eling is more than enough to justify publishing that paper, and I'm gratefu=
l he and his coauthors did not try to obfuscate it with a veil of needless =
quantification.<br>
> <br>
> Best,<br>
> <br>
> ken<br>
